header: Informing policies for Africa's urban future

list.title: Defining urban
list.subTitle: No internationally accepted definition of urban.
list.description: The word city ( mostly refers to a politico-administrative unit whose boundaries and legal status are defined by national governments according to varying administrative, political and/or functional criteria, contexts and objectives.

list.title: Urbanisation dynamics and drivers
list.subTitle: Africa has the fastest urban growth rate in the world.
list.description: By 2050, Africa's urban areas will be home to an additional 950 million people.

list.title: Beyond large cities
list.subTitle: There are only few big cities but many small ones.
list.description: Africa has 11 urban areas with more than five million inhabitants for a combined population of 95 million people, and it counts 6 740 small urban agglomeration with fewer than 100 000 inhabitants home to 180 million.

list.title: Urban agglomeration network
list.subTitle: Distance is a physical as well as a socio-economic concept.
list.description: A total of 320 162 pairings are made by connecting all urban agglomerations that are 120 kilometres or less from one another.

list.title: Cross-border agglomerations in Africa
list.subTitle: In Africa, cities in close proximity are often located across the border from one another.
list.description: More than 42 million people (almost 8% of total urban population) of the continent live in these 645 cross-border cities.

list.title: Top 50 largest agglomerations in Africa
list.subTitle: Twenty of the 50 largest agglomeration by built-up area are in Nigeria and Kenya.
list.description: One of the main drivers of urban growth in Africa is the expansion of built-up areas.
